title: 108_s96
content:
The "Contract With Investors" Act repeals Title IX of the Economic Growth and Tax Relief Reconciliation Act of 2001 and accelerates individual income tax rate reductions to 2004. Additionally, the Act repeals estate and generation-skipping transfer taxes accelerated to 2005. The "Contract With Investors" Act accelerates individual income tax rate reductions to 2004 and repeals estate and generation-skipping transfer taxes by moving the deadlines to 2005 and 2004 respectively. Amendments are made to the Internal Revenue Code to reflect these changes. Amendments are made to the Internal Revenue Code, including accelerating individual income tax rate reductions to 2004 and repealing estate and generation-skipping transfer taxes by moving deadlines to 2005 and 2004 respectively. Various sections of the Code are amended to reflect these changes. Amendments to the Internal Revenue Code include changing deadlines for individual income tax rate reductions to 2004 and repealing estate and generation-skipping transfer taxes by moving deadlines to 2005 and 2004 respectively. Various sections of the Code are updated to reflect these changes. The Economic Growth and Tax Relief Reconciliation Act of 2001 is amended to change deadlines for tax reductions to 2004 instead of 2009. The amendments will take effect upon the enactment of the Act. Reduction of maximum capital gains rates for individuals. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to reduce the maximum capital gains rate for individuals. If a taxpayer has a net capital gain, the tax imposed shall not exceed a certain percentage of the taxpayer's net capital gain or taxable income. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to reduce the maximum capital gains rate for individuals. The tax imposed on net capital gain shall not exceed a certain percentage of the taxpayer's net capital gain or taxable income. Additionally, the taxpayer can elect to take into account investment income for the taxable year under section 163(d)(4)(B)(iii). The minimum tax is also addressed in relation to the maximum rate of tax on net capital gain. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to reduce the maximum capital gains rate for individuals. Section 55(b) is amended by striking paragraph (3). Conforming amendments are made to sections 57(a)(7), 1445(e), and 7518(g)(6)(A) to adjust tax percentages. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to reduce the maximum capital gains rate for individuals to 10 percent. The amendments apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2002, with withholding changes for amounts paid after the same date. SEC. 6. Increase in limitation on capital losses for individuals. Increase in limitation on capital losses for individuals to $10,000 ($5,000 adjusted for inflation) for taxable years beginning after 2003. The taxable year starts with a change from 1992 to 2002. Any increase not a multiple of $5 is rounded up. These amendments apply to taxable years after December 31, 2002. SEC. 7. ACCELERATION OF INCREASE IN CONTRIBUTIONS TO CERTAIN RETIREMENT PLANS. SEC. 7. ACCELERATION OF INCREASE IN CONTRIBUTIONS TO CERTAIN RETIREMENT PLANS.

(a) IRAs: The deductible amount is set at $5,000 with inflation adjustments for 2003 and 2002.

(b) 401(k) Plans: The contribution limit is increased to $15,000 with adjustments to subparagraphs. In section 457 plans, the applicable dollar amount is amended to $15,000 with inflation adjustments. The applicable dollar amount in section 457 plans is adjusted to $15,000 for taxable years starting after December 31, 2003, with inflation adjustments following the same method as section 415(d). Any increase not a multiple of $500 will be rounded down. These amendments apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2002. SEC. 8. Age for beginning mandatory distributions increased to 75. The age for mandatory distributions from pension plans, individual retirement plans, and Roth IRAs is increased from 70 1/2 to 75 under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The age for mandatory distributions from pension plans, individual retirement plans, and Roth IRAs is increased from 70 1/2 to 75 under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, effective for distributions after December 31, 2002. SEC. 116 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 excludes dividends received by individuals from gross income. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 excludes dividends received by individuals from gross income, with certain exceptions for dividends from corporations exempt from tax under section 501 or 521. Special rules apply, including the exclusion not applying to capital gain dividends from regulated investment companies and real estate investment trusts. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 excludes dividends from gross income for individuals, with exceptions for certain dividends. Nonresident aliens are ineligible for exclusion in specific cases. Dividends from employee stock ownership plans are also excluded. Conforming amendments are made to the Code. Amendments are made to various sections of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 regarding the coordination with section 116 for dividends received by participants in common trust funds. Subsection (c) of section 584 is amended to consider the proportionate share of dividends received by participants. Subsection (a) of section 643 is amended to redesignate paragraph (7) as paragraph (8). Amendments are made to various sections of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 regarding the exclusion of dividends received by individuals. Section 854(a) is amended to include section 116 for purposes of dividends. Section 857(c) is amended to address restrictions on dividends received from real estate investment trusts. Amendments to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 exclude dividends received from real estate investment trusts meeting certain requirements from being considered as dividends for tax purposes. Amendments to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 exclude dividends received by individuals from being considered as dividends for tax purposes. Effective starting taxable years after December 31, 2002. The Senate believes Congress should pass legislation to protect workers' pensions, update international tax laws for US companies, eliminate unnecessary regulations on investors and businesses, implement tort reform, and simplify the tax code to reduce business costs.
